DataElement.preferredName: Pathology Review Hematoxylin and Eosin Staining Method Slide FFPE Derivation Histologic Type Eligibility Determination Confirmation Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: An indication of whether the local pathology review of the H&E slide derived from QC FFPE tumor tissue confirmed the histological type eligible for the study.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Pathology Review Hematoxylin and Eosin Staining Method Slide Device Component Fixed Specimen Paraffin Embedded Tissue Derivation Histologic Type Eligibility Determination Confirmation
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The medical science, and specialty practice, concerned with all aspects of disease, but with special reference to the essential nature, causes, and development of abnormal conditions, as well as the structural and functional changes that result from the disease processes. Informally used to mean the result of such an examination._The act of appraisal, evaluation, or analysis._Hematoxylin-and-eosin, or H&E, is a routine staining procedure of tissue sections. This staining method uses two separate dyes, one staining the nucleus and the other staining the cytoplasm and connective tissue. Hematoxylin is a dark purplish dye that stains the chromatin (nuclear material) within the nucleus. Eosin is an orangish-pink to red dye that stains the cytoplasmic material including connective tissue and collagen._A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study._Tissue which is preserved in a fixative solution, usually formalin._Tissue that is preserved and embedded in paraffin._The source from which something comes or issues; to take, obtain, or receive from a source._Refers to the type of tissue in which a tumor originated._Criteria to determine eligibility of patients for medical care programs and services._Having been established or verified.

Concepts.definition: The medical science, and specialty practice, concerned with all aspects of disease, but with special reference to the essential nature, causes, and development of abnormal conditions, as well as the structural and functional changes that result from the disease processes. The act of appraisal, evaluation, or analysis.

Property.preferredName: Hematoxylin and Eosin Staining Method Slide Device Component Fixed Specimen Paraffin Embedded Tissue Derivation Histologic Type Eligibility Determination Confirmation
Property.preferredDefinition: Hematoxylin-and-eosin, or H&E, is a routine staining procedure of tissue sections. This staining method uses two separate dyes, one staining the nucleus and the other staining the cytoplasm and connective tissue. Hematoxylin is a dark purplish dye that stains the chromatin (nuclear material) within the nucleus. Eosin is an orangish-pink to red dye that stains the cytoplasmic material including connective tissue and collagen.:A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.:Tissue which is preserved in a fixative solution, usually formalin.:Tissue that is preserved and embedded in paraffin.:The source from which something comes or issues; to take, obtain, or receive from a source.:Refers to the type of tissue in which a tumor originated.:Criteria to determine eligibility of patients for medical care programs and services.:Having been established or verified.

Concepts.definition: Hematoxylin-and-eosin, or H&E, is a routine staining procedure of tissue sections. This staining method uses two separate dyes, one staining the nucleus and the other staining the cytoplasm and connective tissue. Hematoxylin is a dark purplish dye that stains the chromatin (nuclear material) within the nucleus. Eosin is an orangish-pink to red dye that stains the cytoplasmic material including connective tissue and collagen.
A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.
Tissue which is preserved in a fixative solution, usually formalin.
Tissue that is preserved and embedded in paraffin.
The source from which something comes or issues; to take, obtain, or receive from a source.
Refers to the type of tissue in which a tumor originated.
The act of determining if a subject is suitable for enrollment in a study according specific protocol criteria and procedures.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: trial-specific criteria that a patient must meet to be enrolled.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The preferred Value Domain to indicate a question with permissible values of yes/no.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Concepts.definition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The affirmative response to a question.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Conceptual domain that includes value meanings to be used for Indicator Value Meanings such as Yes, No, Unknown, No Applicable

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A caDSR representation term that is used to indicate a question with permissible values of yes/no

Concepts.definition: A response or indicator that can have a value of either yes or no.

ReferenceDocuments.description: Did pathology review of the H&E slide derived from QC FFPE tumor tissue confirm the histological type to be eligible for BPV study?
